Students to pay for add-drops
By DON LASSUS
Under a new University policy
students will pay increased
penalties for late registration and
course additions and drops
following the first six weeks of a
semester.
The new registration policy
issued April 3 by Vice President
for Homewood George Benton
increases the penalty fee for late
registration from $10 to $25 and
places a $25 fine on course adds
and drops made after the first six
weeks of a semester.
In addition to the fine for late
adds and drops, undergraduates
are also required to obtain
permission for the changes from
the Dean of Academic Programs.
The policy changes go into effect
next fall.
Efficiency
Benton explained the reason
for the policy change as an
attempt to increase the efficiency
of the Registrar's Office.
"Under the $10 fine for late
registration students don't
register when they should,"
Benton noted. "Students feel
that they can afford to register
late for a $10 fine and this gives
the Registrar extra work."
The new policy dictates that
students must register during the
designated registration period
and that any student registering
after the end of that period must
pay a •$25 fine. No student will
be allowed to register after the
first six weeks of a semester.
Included in the policy
statement is the levy of a $25
fine for adds and drops after the
first six weeks of a semester.
Terrible Abuse
"There has been terrible abuse
of the whole add -drop
procedure," Benton complained.
"Students adding and dropping
courses the week before the end
of the semester plays havoc with
an orderly operation."

Benton indicated that the
present system which allows
students to add and drop courses
without penalty until late in the
semester places "an excessive
burden" on the Registrar and
decreases the efficiency of that
office.

He noted that "reasonable
changes" would be allowed with
the permission of the Dean of
Academic Programs.
The registration changes were
included in a general policy
statement covering regulations on
Fees and Registration and
Housing.

The election this week of Andrew Savitz to the
Presidency of the Student Council brings up interesting
prospects for the year ahead. Savitz is the first
freshman elected to that office in memory and his
record as a loudmouth has already won him a wide
reputation on campus.
He will be far different from the low-profile,
unimaginative leaders the SC has had in the past. He
will not hesitate to criticize the people and the
conditions he doesn't like and he just might be able to
do some good for students here.
But Savitz's reputation as a loudmouth will make
little difference to the average Hopkins student unless
the newly-elected president can deliver on his promises.
In his campaign, he has mentioned all the issues that
every one has heard before. Charges that faculty
members don't care about undergradutes, that thereis
little sense of community on campus and that the SC
needs new direction are not new. To be effective,
Savitz must find out what issues are really most
important and concentrate on them. If he does not, the
time wasted on epithets and criticism will be lost to
the students he is supposed to lead and no one will pay
any attention to the SC.
A disorganized group of disinterested people is what
makes student government a farce, but some forceful
direction might make Hopkins student government a
worthwhile venture. Strong leadership is what the SC
needs if it is to accomplish anything. That is something
Savitz can provide if he tries.

Vice President George Benton's decision to penalize
students for changing their course loads late in the
semester brings to the fore whether the University's
interests lie in raising the school out of its financial
bind, or in actually functioning as a place where
students can exercise academic freedom. Changing
courses late in the semester is a perogative that students
should be provided in a forward looking
university.
Students usually plan out their years at Hopkins
with some degree of care, and changes in their
scheduling is not something that they do so very
quickly. Of course, some people do abuse the system,
just as Benton has said, but to penalize most of the
students who use the add-drop system only as a
possible avenue of escape from academic pressure is
hard to understand.
The money that will be raised from the
administrative move just will not be enough to
rationalize these logical complaints. The Registrar's
Office makes so many mistakes now, that it is hard to
see that this move will be able to clear up the greater
portion of the divers errors. Although the funds to be
raised will certainly help the Arts and Sciences Division
out of some of its million dollar debt, the small amount
that the fee will actually bring in will not offset the
move. It just does not seem that the purpose of the
students here should be to make administration easy
for the administrators, as Benton suggests it should be,
but rather the converse should hold true.

Humphrey calls for support in airport briefing
By JIM FELICI
In an atypical "non-campaign" stop in
Baltimore Wednesday night, Senator
Hubert Humphrey preceded dinner and a
speech at the Beth Trioloh Brotherhood
Organization with a press conference at
Friendship Airport. The five hour flash
tour of the area was sandwiched between
campaigning in Pennsylvania and a trip to
Washington to catch up on office
work. The crowd of reporters waiting
for the hour-late Humphrey milled about
amongst the scanty crowd of onlookers
and exhibited a generally bored attitude
concerning the upcoming news
conferences. One of three United
stewardesses deplaning a flight at the next
gate observed an incoming Delta flight
and asked "Is Humphrey on that plane?"
Another turned and asked what seemed to

be the question of the day, "Humphrey
who?" "Hubert Humphrey; the guy who's
running for President" came the reply.
"Oh, that Humphrey," the stewardess
returned.
When Humphrey finally arrived,
winging in on a vintage General Dynamics
prop-driven Convair with the initials
"HHH" painted on the side, a small group
of photographers rushed out to meet him.
Debarking, Humphrey paused for a few
seconds for the photos to do their work,
then heading swiftly over to shake hands
with every member of the grounds crew
he could find. Halfway up the escalator
into the terminal, the "candidate's smile"
suddenly swept over Humphrey's face. At
the top of the escalator the

self-proclaimed "peoples' candidate"
launced into the small crowd grabbing at
every hand in sight, giving each one a firm
shake. After apparently exhausting the
hand supply in the area, he finally walked
up to.the impromptu podium, surrounded
by that time with a circle of six Secret
Service men shoulder to shoulder.
Rhinestones
On the podium he was joined by the
two co-chairmen of his Maryland primary
campaign, Bill Burch and Gladys
Spellman. The latter was tastefully
dressed in a white floor-length formal
gown, adorned several inches above the
hem with the form of a seated feline cut
out of a piece of ocelot hide. The form
was in turn outlined in rhinestones.
Humphrey opened the press conference
with a short prepared statement, in which
he claimed a measure of native status in
Maryland, having lived in the state for
some years while his children were
schooled here. He went on to extoll
Gladys Spellman's role in his campaign,
making some cloudy reference to
women's lib. In the process of asserting
that "Maryland is a very important state,"
Humphrey lauded Governor Marvin
Mandel, casually mentioning that Mandel
just happened to be the chairman of the
Democratic Governor's Conference.
The general tone of the statement,
though, was that "I am running a people's
campaign," declaring Humphrey's
intentions to bring the issues to the
working people.
In response to this declaration about
his concern with working class America,
one reporter inquired about George
Wallace's campaign, and its working class
tone. Aware of Wallace's good labor
'showing in Wisconsin, Humphrey simply
called for "all good Democrats to join in
support of Hubert Humphrey in the state
of Maryland." His phrasing insinuated
heavily that any Democrat who did not
support was not, in his words, either
"good" or "progressive." His main
concern in the Maryland primary, he
stated, was the delegate support he stood
to glean by a good showing here.
Inevitable Question
When the inevitable question of the
Viet Nam war arose, he rattled off a quick
answer, apparently memorized by virtue
of repeated use over the last four years.
He said "I believe we should be getting
out as rapidly as possible while assuring
safety for our troops." Somehow that
sounded familiar. The only thing he had

to say on the war issue which hadn't
been said by every other candidate at
some time or other was a
recommendation that the war question be
referred to the Security Council of the
U.N. In addition to pacifying critics at
home, this would have the added
advantage of testing China's new role in
the Security Council.
When asked about George McGovern
and his campaign, Humphrey responded
in a serious tone,"Mr. McGovern is a very
fine man."
Humphrey claimed he was not a
machine man, but rather a man of the
people, and charged that the Democratic
machine in Pennsylvania was trying to
railroad his primary efforts in that state.
By affiliating McGovern with the ever
odious political 'machine, Humphrey, the
master of the backhand mudsling, had in
effect accused McGovern of the alleged
railroading efforts. This comment was also
acted as a kind of foreshadowing that
seems to indicate that Humphrey may be
in trouble in Pennsylvania.
As one of his aides pressed him to wrap
the session up, he made some concluding
remarks which consisted of trying to
convince the listeners that he actually
cared about Maryland at all. It seemed
rather obvious though, that his main
priorities were Ohio and Pennsylvania.
Candidates Delight
Turning to leave, he was again
surrounded by his cordon of Secret
Service men. Surrounded, that is, until he
spotted a candidate's delight: a young
mother with her little girl. Shaking hands
with Humphrey, the little girl was told by
her mother, "Why, if he gets elected you
will have shaken hands with the President

of the United States!" The kid didn't
seem very impressed.
Once again, the procession got under
way, the cordon reforming about
Humphrey. Suddenly, Mr. Humphrey did
a double take to his left, and stopped
dead in his tracks. What a target! Three
Marines and a sailor! With the reflexes of
a cat, Humphrey's hand shot out, and a
grin hit his face so hard that he began to
squint. He bolted through the line of
security men, and the hand shaking began
anew with these representatives of the
military. When it was all over, they
walked away laughing.

Humphrey calls for support in airport briefing
By JIM FELICI
In an atypical "non-campaign" stop in
Baltimore Wednesday night, Senator
Hubert Humphrey preceded dinner and a
speech at the Beth Trioloh Brotherhood
Organization with a press conference at
Friendship Airport. The five hour flash
tour of the area was sandwiched between
campaigning in Pennsylvania and a trip to
Washington to catch up on office
work. The crowd of reporters waiting
for the hour-late Humphrey milled about
amongst the scanty crowd of onlookers
and exhibited a generally bored attitude
concerning the upcoming news
conferences. One of three United
stewardesses deplaning a flight at the next
gate observed an incoming Delta flight
and asked "Is Humphrey on that plane?"
Another turned and asked what seemed to

be the question of the day, "Humphrey
who?" "Hubert Humphrey; the guy who's
running for President" came the reply.
"Oh, that Humphrey," the stewardess
returned.
When Humphrey finally arrived,
winging in on a vintage General Dynamics
prop-driven Convair with the initials
"HHH" painted on the side, a small group
of photographers rushed out to meet him.
Debarking, Humphrey paused for a few
seconds for the photos to do their work,
then heading swiftly over to shake hands
with every member of the grounds crew
he could find. Halfway up the escalator
into the terminal, the "candidate's smile"
suddenly swept over Humphrey's face. At
the top of the escalator the

self-proclaimed "peoples' candidate"
launced into the small crowd grabbing at
every hand in sight, giving each one a firm
shake. After apparently exhausting the
hand supply in the area, he finally walked
up to.the impromptu podium, surrounded
by that time with a circle of six Secret
Service men shoulder to shoulder.
Rhinestones
On the podium he was joined by the
two co-chairmen of his Maryland primary
campaign, Bill Burch and Gladys
Spellman. The latter was tastefully
dressed in a white floor-length formal
gown, adorned several inches above the
hem with the form of a seated feline cut
out of a piece of ocelot hide. The form
was in turn outlined in rhinestones.
Humphrey opened the press conference
with a short prepared statement, in which
he claimed a measure of native status in
Maryland, having lived in the state for
some years while his children were
schooled here. He went on to extoll
Gladys Spellman's role in his campaign,
making some cloudy reference to
women's lib. In the process of asserting
that "Maryland is a very important state,"
Humphrey lauded Governor Marvin
Mandel, casually mentioning that Mandel
just happened to be the chairman of the
Democratic Governor's Conference.
The general tone of the statement,
though, was that "I am running a people's
campaign," declaring Humphrey's
intentions to bring the issues to the
working people.
In response to this declaration about
his concern with working class America,
one reporter inquired about George
Wallace's campaign, and its working class
tone. Aware of Wallace's good labor
'showing in Wisconsin, Humphrey simply
called for "all good Democrats to join in
support of Hubert Humphrey in the state
of Maryland." His phrasing insinuated
heavily that any Democrat who did not
support was not, in his words, either
"good" or "progressive." His main
concern in the Maryland primary, he
stated, was the delegate support he stood
to glean by a good showing here.
Inevitable Question
When the inevitable question of the
Viet Nam war arose, he rattled off a quick
answer, apparently memorized by virtue
of repeated use over the last four years.
He said "I believe we should be getting
out as rapidly as possible while assuring
safety for our troops." Somehow that
sounded familiar. The only thing he had

to say on the war issue which hadn't
been said by every other candidate at
some time or other was a
recommendation that the war question be
referred to the Security Council of the
U.N. In addition to pacifying critics at
home, this would have the added
advantage of testing China's new role in
the Security Council.
When asked about George McGovern
and his campaign, Humphrey responded
in a serious tone,"Mr. McGovern is a very
fine man."
Humphrey claimed he was not a
machine man, but rather a man of the
people, and charged that the Democratic
machine in Pennsylvania was trying to
railroad his primary efforts in that state.
By affiliating McGovern with the ever
odious political 'machine, Humphrey, the
master of the backhand mudsling, had in
effect accused McGovern of the alleged
railroading efforts. This comment was also
acted as a kind of foreshadowing that
seems to indicate that Humphrey may be
in trouble in Pennsylvania.
As one of his aides pressed him to wrap
the session up, he made some concluding
remarks which consisted of trying to
convince the listeners that he actually
cared about Maryland at all. It seemed
rather obvious though, that his main
priorities were Ohio and Pennsylvania.
Candidates Delight
Turning to leave, he was again
surrounded by his cordon of Secret
Service men. Surrounded, that is, until he
spotted a candidate's delight: a young
mother with her little girl. Shaking hands
with Humphrey, the little girl was told by
her mother, "Why, if he gets elected you
will have shaken hands with the President

of the United States!" The kid didn't
seem very impressed.
Once again, the procession got under
way, the cordon reforming about
Humphrey. Suddenly, Mr. Humphrey did
a double take to his left, and stopped
dead in his tracks. What a target! Three
Marines and a sailor! With the reflexes of
a cat, Humphrey's hand shot out, and a
grin hit his face so hard that he began to
squint. He bolted through the line of
security men, and the hand shaking began
anew with these representatives of the
military. When it was all over, they
walked away laughing.
